title: What is the relation between Mephisto in Lord Byron, Mesmerism, and James Braid's neuroipnology?
first_phrase: The text delves into the history and evolution of mesmerism, starting with Lord Byron's depiction of Mephisto in Cain, Act i. Scene 1, and going on to discuss Franz Anton Mesmer's methodology, which was initially popularized in Austria and then in France. Additionally, the works of Theophrastus Paracelsus and William Maxwell are mentioned alongside contemporary therapies that seem to rediscover the principles of Mesmer's approach to psychoanalysis. The text also touches on Charles Lafontaine's criticism of James Braid's attempt to create his own system by magnetizing himself while denying the effects of magnetism. The concluding portion of the text cites research by Mulholland and Peper, who discovered that eye convergence leads to greater production of alpha waves connected to relaxation.

last_phrase: In conclusion, various modern therapies seem to rediscover some elements already identified by Mesmer and interpreted psychoanalytically. As James Braid notes, any bright object when concentrated upon for some time can induce hypnosis, but the effectiveness of hypnosis varies from person to person. While hypnosis and magnetic therapy may have their limitations, understanding and utilizing their methods in conjunction with other medical and chemical practices may offer the best results.
